questions.question: A 12yo boy has foot pain/inflammation and red streaks up the leg. He removed a wood splinter from the sole yesterday. The likely organism is:
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation of red streaks extending up the limb (lymphangitis) following a puncture wound is characteristic of a Streptococcal infection (Group A Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 24yo male, 60min post foot puncture, has a nail in the sole, erythema, minimal bleeding, no purulence. Tetanus status unknown. How to manage potential tetanus?
options: Local wound care, IV metronidazole or penicillin for 7 to 10 days
Local wound care, IV metronidazole or penicillin for 7 to 10 days, tetanus toxoid
Local wound care, IV abx 7-10d, tetanus toxoid, tetanus Ig
questions.explanation: For dirty wounds with unknown immunization, guidelines recommend Tetanus Toxoid (active) and Immunoglobulin (passive). Antibiotics are also indicated.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 30yo woman has open appendectomy (no antibiotics) for perforation. She develops an intra-abdominal abscess. Which organism is likely responsible?
questions.explanation: Bacteroides fragilis is the common anaerobe in abdominal abscesses after perforation. It is associated with abscess encapsulation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 4.5kg infant, born following un-complicated labor and delivery, is noted to have a uni-lateral cleft lip and palate. The parents should be advised to:
options: The child almost has other congenital anomalies
Lip repair is indicated at 1 year of age
Palate repair is indicated prior to 6 mo. of age
questions.explanation: Cleft lip/palate needs multidisciplinary care (speech therapy). Lip repair is done at 3-6 months, palate repair at 9-12 months.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman undergoes wide excision of a pigmented lesion of her thigh. Pathologic examination reveals malignant melanoma that is Clark's level IV. findings on examination of the groin are normal. The patient should be advised that:
options: Radiotherapy will be an important part of subsequent therapy
Immuno-therapy is an effective form of adjunctive treatment for metastatic malignant melanoma
Groin dissection is not indicated unless and until groin nodes become palpable
Intra-lesional BCG aids local control in most patients
questions.explanation: Without palpable nodes, prophylactic dissection is controversial. Dissection is typically reserved for when nodes become palpable (therapeutic).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 45yo woman gets cephalosporin for cholecystectomy. 1 week later: fever, diarrhea, diagnosed with pseudomembranous colitis. Which statement is correct?
options: After appropriate antibiotic therapy, the relapse rate is less than 5%
Toxin B tissue culture is not sensitive/specific; diagnosis is clinical
Surgery indicated for failure, toxic megacolon, or perforation
questions.explanation: C. diff is treated medically. Colectomy is reserved for toxic megacolon, perforation, or medical failure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with a painless, ulcerated lesion on his right check, 1 year ago with no lymph node enlargement neck reveals. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer, often presenting as a painless ulcerated nodule ('rodent ulcer') on the face in older adults. It rarely metastasizes to lymph nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A patient has burns in one leg (circumferential), one arm (circumferential) and the anterior trunk; what are the percentages of burn does the patient have?
questions.explanation: Using the Rule of Nines: One leg (18%) + One arm (9%) + Anterior trunk (18%) = 45% TBSA.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Clark Level IV of classification extends to which of the following structures:
questions.explanation: Clark levels classify melanoma depth: Level I (Epidermis), II (Papillary dermis), III (Junction), IV (Reticular dermis), and V (Subcutaneous fat).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Management of leukoplakia of the oral cavity includes:
questions.explanation: Leukoplakia is a pre-malignant lesion often caused by chronic irritation. The initial management involves removing irritants, such as correcting ill-fitting dentures or stopping smoking.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Recovered from burn wounds is:
questions.explanation: Candida species are the most common non-bacterial (fungal) organisms recovered from burn wounds.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The appropriate antibiotic to describe while awaiting specific culture verification is:
questions.explanation: In the context of classic surgical infections like cellulitis (Strep) or gas gangrene (Clostridium), Penicillin G is the historical empirical choice mentioned in this dataset.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The appropriate management of a deep partial-thickness burn is:
questions.explanation: Deep partial-thickness burns heal with significant scarring and have a high risk of infection. Early excision and skin grafting is the standard of care to optimize functional and cosmetic outcomes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent non-bacterial, opportunistic organism recovered from burn wounds is:
questions.explanation: Candida is the most frequent fungal pathogen found in burn wounds, often capitalizing on the immunocompromised state and broad-spectrum antibiotic use.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: True statements regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the lip include:
options: The lesion arises in areas of persistent hyperkeratosis
>90% of cases occur on the upper lip
Radiography is considered inappropriate treatment for these lesions
Initially metastases are to the ipsilateral posterior cervical lymph nodes
questions.explanation: SCC of the lip often arises from precursor lesions like actinic cheilitis (persistent hyperkeratosis). It most commonly affects the LOWER lip (>90%) and metastasizes to submental/submandibular nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following cases is considered clean contaminated wound:
options: Gunshot wound to the abdomen with injuries to small bowel and sigmoid colon
questions.explanation: A clean-contaminated wound involves entering a hollow viscus (respiratory, GI, genital, urinary) under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Cholecystectomy fits this category.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding carpal tunnel syndrome is correct?
options: It most often causes parathesia during waking hours
Associated with vascular compromise; surgery releases extensor retinaculum
questions.explanation: Carpal tunnel syndrome is common in pregnancy due to fluid retention causing compression of the median nerve. Symptoms are typically worse at night (nocturnal paresthesia).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard cl. tetani all are correct except:
questions.explanation: C. tetani usually has a drumstick appearance. The key marks this as the exception. Incubation is typically 8-12 days, not 3-5.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard incubation period of tetanus:
options: May occur up to 3weeks of wound
The shorter the incubation period the poorer the prognosis
questions.explanation: The incubation period of tetanus is variable, typically 3-21 days. While 'All of the above' describes true statements, the provided key selects 'Variable' as the primary answer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Collar stud abscess is common with which type of hand infection:
questions.explanation: A collar-stud abscess forms when a superficial abscess (like a subcuticular whitlow) communicates with a deeper abscess cavity through a small opening in the dermis or fascia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Erysipelas differs from cellulitis in:
options: Erysipelas has sharply demarcated indurated edges
questions.explanation: The hallmark of erysipelas is a sharply demarcated, raised border (step-off) that distinguishes involved skin from uninvolved skin. It involves the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Incubation period of gas gangrene is about:
questions.explanation: Standard texts say gas gangrene incubation is 1-4 days. The key selects '1-2 weeks', a discrepancy students should note.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Main pathogenic factor in tetanus is:
options: Exotoxin acting on anterior horn cells and motor end plates
questions.explanation: Medically, tetanus is caused by the exotoxin Tetanospasmin (Option C). However, the provided model answer is 'Hypersensitivity reaction' (D), which contradicts standard medical facts.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common risk factor for carbuncle:
questions.explanation: Diabetes Mellitus (DM) is the most significant predisposing factor for carbuncles (aggregates of infected follicles), typically caused by Staph aureus.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sachrolytic group of clostridia include the following except:
questions.explanation: Cl. histolyticum is proteolytic; Cl. septicum is saccharolytic. The key incorrectly marks Cl. septicum as the exception.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sign of victory is suggestive of:
questions.explanation: The 'Sign of Victory' refers to the V-shaped separation of adjacent fingers, which is a clinical sign of a web space infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best site for incision of ulnar bursa abscess is:
questions.explanation: Drainage of the ulnar bursa is typically performed via an incision along the lateral (radial) border of the hypothenar eminence to avoid the ulnar neurovascular bundle.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most appropriate treatment for a case of gas gangrene with multi- organ dysfunction and established muscle necrosis is:
options: Debridement of dead muscle and limb salvage
questions.explanation: In severe gas gangrene with established necrosis and systemic toxicity (MOF), amputation is often life-saving and the definitive treatment to remove the source of toxin production.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most feared complication of Ludwig angina is:
questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina is a submandibular/sublingual space infection that can displace the tongue posteriorly, leading to acute airway obstruction and suffocation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Lymph granuloma venereum is caused by:
questions.explanation: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Proper treatment for frostbite consists of:
options: Debridement of the affected part followed by silver sulfadiazine dressing
Immersion of the affected part in water at 40 - 44 °C
Re-warming of the affected part at room temperature
questions.explanation: The mainstay of frostbite treatment is rapid rewarming by immersion in circulating warm water (40-42°C or 104-108°F) until the tissue becomes pliable.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is the most common melanoma in dark-skinned people?
questions.explanation: Acral lentiginous melanoma (occurring on palms, soles, and nail beds) is the most common subtype of melanoma in dark-skinned individuals.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The presence of sulfur granules in a draining wound should lead to the use of which of the following antibiotics:
questions.explanation: Sulfur granules are pathognomonic for Actinomycosis. The treatment of choice for Actinomyces israelii is high-dose Penicillin.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of melanoma?
questions.explanation: Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common subtype, accounting for approximately 70% of all melanoma cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A patient with a 3-mm deep melanoma of the face with a clinically +ve jugular node should undergo what procedure in addition to resection of the primary?
options: Modified radical neck dissection and superficial parotidectomy
questions.explanation: Clinically palpable (positive) lymph nodes in melanoma require therapeutic lymph node dissection. For the neck, a Modified Radical Neck Dissection is the standard.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following statements about Kaposi's sarcoma in patients with acquired immune-deficiency syndrome (AIDS) are correct Except:
options: Lesions are rubbery blue nodules that resemble hemangiomas
The gastro-intestinal tract is often involved
Intra-venous drug abusers are frequently affected
questions.explanation: Epidemiologically, AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma is strongly associated with sexual transmission (HHV-8) and is much more common in homosexual men than in IV drug users.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: An infection with Staphylococcus aureus acquired in an intensive care unit should be treated initially with:
questions.explanation: Hospital-acquired (nosocomial) Staph aureus, especially in the ICU, has a high probability of being Methicillin-Resistant (MRSA). Vancomycin is the initial drug of choice.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Infections that require operative treatment include all of the following Except:
questions.explanation: Infected ascites is treated medically. Empyema, necrotizing fasciitis, and graft infections require surgery.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Patients with a penicillin allergy are LEAST likely to have a cross-reaction with:
questions.explanation: Monobactams (Aztreonam) have a unique structure with almost no cross-reactivity to penicillin, making them safe.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Staphylococcus aureus produces each of the following Except:
questions.explanation: Staph aureus produces enterotoxins and epidermolytic toxins, but not neurotoxins (characteristic of Clostridium).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best antibiotic for post-exposure prophylaxis to Bacillus anthracis (anthrax) is:
questions.explanation: Guidelines favor Ciprofloxacin/Doxycycline. The key selects Clindamycin (usually adjunctive). Note the discrepancy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The classic chest X-ray finding in anthrax is:
questions.explanation: Inhalational anthrax causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis, which presents classically as a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The drug of choice for clostridial myonecrosis is:
questions.explanation: High-dose Penicillin G is the traditional drug of choice for Clostridial myonecrosis (Gas Gangrene), often combined with protein synthesis inhibitors like Clindamycin.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most appropriate treatment of a 4-cm hepatic abscess is:
options: Aspiration for culture and anti-biotic therapy
Operative exploration, open drainage of the abscess and anti-biotic therapy
questions.explanation: Percutaneous drainage (combined with antibiotics) is the standard first-line treatment for accessible pyogenic hepatic abscesses, especially those larger than 3-5 cm.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The tumor, node, metastases classification for melanoma uses the following in its classification Except:
options: Vertical thickness of the primary tumor
questions.explanation: TNM staging for melanoma uses Tumor thickness (Breslow depth), Nodal status, and Metastasis (which includes LDH levels). General 'Serum protein level' is not a staging criterion.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is the most commonly acquired infection in hospitalized surgical patients?
questions.explanation: Surgical Site Infections (SSI) are the most common nosocomial infections specifically in surgical patients (typically 38% of such infections).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is the most effective way to prevent post-operative seroma/infection in an obese patient after an open appendectomy?
options: Leaving the subcutaneous tissue and skin open to heal by secondary intention
Closing the wound a rubber drain
Closing the wound with a closed suction drain
Closing the wound with multiple sutures in the subcutaneous tissue
questions.explanation: In obese patients, the thick subcutaneous layer is prone to dead space and seroma formation. A closed suction drain is often effective in preventing fluid accumulation and subsequent infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 65-year-old farmer presents with a 1.5-cm ulcerated lesion on the middle third of his lower lip. The lesion has been present for 4 months and is not painful. No lymph nodes are palpable in the patient's neck. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) is the most common malignancy of the lip (specifically lower lip), associated with chronic sun exposure (farmers) and presenting as a non-healing ulcer.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common site of actinomycosis:
questions.explanation: The cervicofacial region (Head and neck) is the most common site for actinomycosis infection, often associated with dental pathology or trauma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most desirable position to immobilize the hand:
options: Wrist is flexed, MCP joints are extended and lP joints are flexed
Wrist is flexed. MCP joints are flexed and lP joints are extended
Wrist is extended, MCP joints are extended and lP joints are flexed
Wrist is extended. MCP joints are flexed and lP joints are flexed
Wrist is extended, MCP joints are flexed and lP joints are extended
questions.explanation: The 'Position of Safety' or Intrinsic Plus position involves wrist extension (20-30 deg), MCP flexion (70-90 deg), and IP extension. This prevents collateral ligament shortening and contractures.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best cosmetic results for large capillary (port wine) hemangiomas are achieved by:
questions.explanation: Pulsed dye laser therapy is the gold standard for treating port-wine stains (capillary malformations), offering the best cosmetic outcome with minimal scarring.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.explanation: C. tetani usually has a drumstick appearance. The key marks this as the exception. Incubation is typically 8-12 days, not 3-5.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard incubation period of tetanus:
options: May occur up to 3weeks of wound
The shorter the incubation period the poorer the prognosis
questions.explanation: The incubation period of tetanus is variable, ranging from 3 days to 3 weeks, with an average of 8-10 days. A shorter incubation period is associated with a poorer prognosis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Collar stud abscess is common with which type of hand infection:
questions.explanation: A collar-stud abscess forms when a superficial infection (like a subcuticular whitlow or infected blister) communicates with a deeper abscess cavity through a small opening in the dermis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Erysipelas differs from cellulitis in:
options: Erysipelas has sharply demarcated indurated edges
questions.explanation: Erysipelas involves the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics, resulting in a sharply demarcated, raised border (step-off). Cellulitis involves deeper tissues and has indistinct borders.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Incubation period of gas gangrene is about:
questions.explanation: Standard texts say gas gangrene incubation is 1-4 days. The key selects '1-2 weeks', a discrepancy students should note.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Main pathogenic factor in tetanus is:
options: Exotoxin acting on anterior horn cells and motor end plates
questions.explanation: Tetanus is caused by tetanospasmin exotoxin blocking inhibitory transmitters. The provided key selects 'Hypersensitivity', which contradicts standard pathophysiology.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common risk factor for carbuncle:
questions.explanation: Carbuncles are extensive, coalescing infections of hair follicles and subcutaneous tissue. Diabetes Mellitus is the most significant risk factor due to impaired immune response.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sachrolytic group of clostridia include the following except:
questions.explanation: Cl. histolyticum is proteolytic; Cl. septicum is saccharolytic. The key incorrectly marks Cl. septicum as the exception.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sign of victory is suggestive of:
questions.explanation: The 'Sign of Victory' is the spontaneous V-shaped separation of adjacent fingers caused by swelling in the web space, indicative of a web space infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best site for incision of ulnar bursa abscess is:
questions.explanation: To drain the ulnar bursa, an incision is made along the lateral (radial) border of the hypothenar eminence. This avoids damage to the ulnar neurovascular bundle located medially.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most appropriate treatment for a case of gas gangrene with multi- organ dysfunction and established muscle necrosis is:
options: Debridement of dead muscle and limb salvage
questions.explanation: In advanced gas gangrene with multi-organ failure and extensive necrosis, immediate amputation is often the only life-saving measure to remove the source of toxin production.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most feared complication of Ludwig angina is:
questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina causes rapid swelling of the submandibular and sublingual spaces, displacing the tongue posteriorly and superiorly, which can lead to fatal airway obstruction (suffocation).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Lymph granuloma venereum is caused by:
questions.explanation: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3.

Immersion of the affected part in water at 40 - 44 °C
Re-warming of the affected part at room temperature
questions.explanation: Rapid rewarming of the frozen part in circulating water at 40-42°C (104-108°F) is the standard of care to minimize tissue loss. Temperatures above 45°C can cause thermal injury.

questions.question: What is the most common melanoma in dark-skinned people?
questions.explanation: Acral lentiginous melanoma occurs on non-hair-bearing skin like palms, soles, and nail beds. It is the most common subtype in individuals with darker skin pigmentation.
